reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Leaving aside all the literary associations, Rohet Garh, 40km outside Jodhpur in Rajasthan is a great place to retreat from the pressures of touring India. A former sprawling fortified maharajah's residence built around a beautiful garden which the owners have turned into a luxurious hotel. The rooms are spacious and comfortable; ours which was once part of the stables had lovely window seats overlooking a lake and the bathrooms are large with modern fittings and great shower.
reviews.title: A peaceful garden paradise

likes.liked: — The interesting rooms and the garden

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: You are welcomed with tea on the shady lawns and the owners take delight in greeting their guests and making them feel welcomed to their family home. Meals are served in a rather nonedescript room by the swimming pool. The food is good but not exceptional and the breakfast is really only average.
reviews.title: Wonderful Heritage Hotel
Loved it
reviews.text: I'd firmly agree with the previous review. This is a lovely and authentic heritage hotel less than an hour's drive south of Jodhpur, making it a great place to stay en route to or from southern Rajasthan. We only stayed one night and it wasn't really enough - we should have stayed longer, but at least this means that we'll have to return sometime !

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The beautifully manicured lawn and large swimming pool make the outside areas a joy to relax in. The restaurant offers good, authentic Rajasthani food and the stable houses a collection of beautiful Marwari horses.
reviews.title: A welcome respite

reviews.text: The jeep safari is excellent and well worth the effort, especially if your guide is as knowledgeable as ours was. The only disappointment was the Kerala massage which was truly forgettable !
reviews.title: seriously disappointing
Rohet Garh
reviews.text: Rohet Garh was the highlight of our Rajasthan trip. It's off the beaten track although a few travel companies do take their tours here if only for a night. We travelled independently and treated ourselves to 3 nights - and would happily have stayed longer. The aristocratic owners have not only converted their palatial property for tourists, they are attempting sustainable tourism for the 70 or so surrounding villages still under their care. The grounds, common rooms and hotel rooms are individual (they have 2-3 painters who are brothers who have a full-time job handpainting and decoarting the rooms), spacious and relaxing. Very enjoyable for instance is the open verandah bar where on comfortable sofas you can sip a drink. We had a 2-storeyed suite with a verandah with swing and a rooftop terrace with a view of the peacocks which wander into the garden towards evening. We went on the village safari - our only real opportunity to see some rural alternatives- and one of us went riding at dawn; there are very well kept stables.

reviews.title: confortable
reviews.text: Yet what we enjoyed most was that we could wander around the village of Rohet unaccosted. The village is tidy and non-obtrusive ( a very welcome change) and we enjoyed going into the local shops and were even invited into a few homes. The shop on the hotel grounds sells handcrafts made locally and part of the profits go to a local charity. This policy can only be applauded and permeated our entire stay.

reviews.title: Skip it
reviews.text: If, like us, you feel you deserve a break from deserts and palaces and museums and camels - then book yourself a few days of paradise here!

Our rooms were comfortable and clean. While we had just come from a fabulous Heritage Hotel in Dungarpur, we were a bit disappointed once we got to Rohet but this was due to the fact that our previous hotel ( Udai Bilas Palace, Dungarpur) had been so spectacular.
reviews.title: Real India
